column2: karena, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have taken the original Maxalt mfg'd by Merck Sharp & Dohme for several years; recently my pharmacare coverage switched me to the "generic" from Sandoz, and now I get regularly parasthesias upon taking a 10 mg dose. They are supposed to be the same (Merck and Sandoz) though I have discerned that the original had 2.1 mg of phenylalanine and the Sandoz version for the same 10 mg. pill contains 3.14 mg of phenylalanine. Could that make the difference?

column2: gsdfan, 55-64 on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have had migraines since I was a teenager and used a number of medications.  MaxAlt has exceeded all others.  On rare occasions, I may need to take more than one.  There are some negatives.  It is very expensive and either not covered or only partially covered by most insurance.  The patent expires this year and I am hoping for a more reasonably priced generic.  Also, the invidual pill packaging is unnecessarily frustrating to open when you're dealing with a headache.Like others have mentioned, it does make me drowsy and I do not drive within a couple of hours of taking it since I feel my reflexes are definitely off.  It also makes me very cold, probably because it is a vaso-constrictor.I do carry it with me at all times, and I'm thankful to have it available since I toughed it out for years without it.

column2: wildhockey, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I never leave home without this medicine. Also, I keep one next to my bed in case I wake up with the beast migraine! I wish this medicine was out years ago. Life has certainly better ever since. This is expensive, but worth every cent! Thank you.

column2: me, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My doctor should have warned me about this since I have had a several verterberbasialar TIAs and strokes & angina.  Talk about making matters worse. MAXALT should not be given to patients with ischemic heart disease (e.g., angina pectoris, history of myocardial infarction, or documented silent ischemia) or to patients who have symptoms or findings consistent with ischemic heart disease, coronary artery vasospasm, including Prinzmetal's variant angina, or other significant underlying cardiovascular disease. MAXALT should not be administered to patients with hemiplegic or basilar migraine.

column2: Lee Ross, 75 or over Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Like other treatments, take at the first sign. Sometimes it only last 6 or so hours. At the intruction of my Dr I now take 2 Aleve with it. I have not experienced any side effects.

column2: wendy-niagara falls, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

column2: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I love my maxalt, it is a miracle worker. I honestly could say I couldn't live without it. column2: jesus4me, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)

column2: Kim, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I love how quickly it works and only one time did I need to take two.  It can make me sleepy but most of the time I'm fine. The benefit of the relief is far greater than the worry of if it'll make me feel tired.  Within 30 minutes of taking I can function again - at work or at home.

column2: DuhMe, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)

column2: csmommy8, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)

column2: empressjp, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more
column9: Been suffering from migraines (with aura) since i was a kid (but didnt know that at the time)...have taken many different drugs for them over the years...started maxalt about 10 years ago...for the most part, it has helped tremendously with my headaches.  Most of the time, it gets rid of a good part of the pain, where i can somewhat function.  I do, however, get EXTREMELY tired from it.  I take a 10 mg pill and down a cup of regular coffee at onset of aura...the coffee has been an additional help...but,while im exhausted from the maxalt and want to sleep in the worst way, the caffeine has other ideas...thats the sucky part.  there have been a few times when the maxalt has done absolutely nothing for me.  I dont always get nausea & vomiting. There have been numerous times when i'll get a headache, go through the hours of pain, and just when its finally coming down...another one will start, so i take more maxalt...there have been times when i will get 3 or 4 of them in a row...and the day after...not fun either...i call it "the hangover day" cause thats how my head feels!!!!

column2: annag61, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)

column2: 25-34 Female  (Patient)
TawnyMarie, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I had migraines on and off through high school.  Usually ibuprofen did the trick.  Now in my mid 20's I've experienced them like never before.  VERY painful and nothing would touch them.  I refused to take any kind of narcotic or pain med because there's always risk of addiction. Maxalt works wonderfully.  I've tried Epidrin and Imitrex as well.  Epidrin didn't do much for me if I had already woken up with the migraine etc which is normally the case and Imitrex made my stomach hurt really bad.  Maxalt is great and I'm glad I have it but, am very disappointed in my insurance company because they only approve 24 pills a month.  It's very unfortunate...I hear this is the case with most insurance companies even if you give the generic with ALL triptans...I actually have frequent migraines.  I'm in the process of seeing an N.D. (Naturopath Doctor) to work on lifestyle changes and possibly herbal/vitamin supplements.  At 26 I just hate to think I'm going to be depending on a med probably for the rest of my life...I'm going to keep using maxalt for the attacks but, am in the process of trying to control triggers etc...

column2: Nonstop golfer, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: My migraines tend to come on slowly.  First I just feel tired and a "bit off"...then nausea, neck and head tension, and finally difficulty with cognition and head pounding.  The earlier I recognize the symptoms, the quicker response I get from Maxalt.  Sometimes I get complete relief in as little as 20 minutes using 1/2 of a 5 mg tablet.  Occasionally I get only partial relief so take the second 1/2 tab. I don't need to hit the bed either.Previously I used Imitrex.  It made me sleepy for hours and I ended up in bed.  I always got rebound headaches with that. My daughter (age 31) has not been so lucky.  She took Maxalt once and her chest pounded, heart rate slowed, and she became too weak to stand.  (She does take a lot of other medications, including an antidepressant,so clearly had a drug interaction.)  Now she is trying Midrin--which hasn't helped so far.

column2: panda, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Maxalt has been a lifesaver for me. Nothing else has worked (except Toradol injection). Occasionally I have side effects with it, but they pass in a relatively short time (tiredness, tightness in chest, arm tingling). They only happen occasionally and not all together. I find if I eat something before I take it, I don't have them. My only complaint is it takes between an hour and 2 to work. If it doesn't relieve the migraine at that point, I take a dose of Motrin and that will wipe it out. i don't know what I would do without it.

This is my lifesaver and the only medication that works for my migraines- and believe me i've taken them all! not even an emergency room shot when i ran out of maxalt did the trick. LOVE THIS MEDICINE!

column2: lacoleson, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column9: I was prescribed maxault because I get really bad basilar artery migraines.  The first time that I took this medication it worked.  However, the second time I took it it caused my heart to race really fast and hard.  My resting heart rate was somewhere in the 170's.  Last night I took it and it didn't cause my heart to race but it did cause it to pound and feel somewhat labored.  This medicine really scares me and I'm not taking it again!

column2: evelazquez, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had tightness in my throat and numbness in my hands. Maxalt also made extremely tired afterwards. However, the headache always went away. I was just unable to function from the extreme sleepiness. Side effects got to be too much, so I stopped taking. I am looking forward to trying Relpax, which is said to have fewer side effects.

column2: jg6271, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I used Maxalt for almost 2 years during the worst of my migraine headaches. I have had migraines for as long as I remember but for a couple of years they worsened to the point where i was having them 2 to 3 times a week. I always throw up from my migraines, and usually I feel like slamming my head in a door just to make it stop. I tried 3 other medicines (imitrex was one, can't remember the others) and none of them worked half as well as Maxalt. I usually had to lie down for it to work the most efficiently, but I would take that anyday over not working at all! After the first year of using Maxalt I did develop a tightening sensation in my jaw and chest after taking it, but it was mainly just slightly annoying, not painful. One note: OTC sinus medications taken within 2 hours of taking Maxalt caused me to get so drowsy I couldn't function. My doctor actually warned me about this but I misjudged the amount of time that had passed and, let me tell you, it knocked me on my butt!  Overall, I would definitely recommend Maxalt to anyone that has migraines. In fact, mine have been increasing in frequency lately so I may be taking it again myself!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This medication is a miracle! It gets rid of my migraines with in about a half an hour.

column2: cmiller, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have tried imitrex and topamax in the past and now use maxalt to relieve migraines. I prefer the 10mg tablets, which I break in half, so that I am getting as small an effective dose as possible. Usually, within 1 hour of taking half a tablet, the pain has subsided. If I haven't gotten relief within 2-3 hours, I will take the other half. If the headache returns within 24 hours, I usually take another tablet (or half if the pain is fairly mild), but I try to take as little as possible to alleviate my symptoms (I usually don't get the 'aura' with migraines, but I frequently experience depression, lack of appetite, some dizziness and lethargy, and occasionally nausea). Sometimes, if the pain is severe or comes on suddenly, I'll take the maxalt and also take one or two excedrin tablets. The combination of acetamenophin, caffeine and aspirin really seems to help. Maxalt (and other drugs of its type) are absolute God-sends for migraine sufferers, and I have never experienced any serious negative side effects. Sometimes I feel slightly 'logey,' and if I lie down I'll fall asleep, but if I need to keep going, the drowsiness will last a few minutes and then go away completely. As for me, topamax decreased my incidences of migraine, but I did not like the side effects, so after about four months, I carefully weaned myself off of it.

column2: nicoleigh33, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

Tolerable or would you rather have a migraine.Email me at nicoleigh33@hotmail.com if you are open to sharing your experience with either drug.Thanks! Nicole

Dr. switched me to this - I don't find it quite as effective- sometimes I have to take 2 pills - but I can at least function when I'm on it. Works in about an hour for me, but then I feel like I need a nap.  I worry that I take too much of it b/c I get several migraines per week, but couldn't live w/o it.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had been using Maxalt and my headaches would go away within 10 min.  I tried the dissolving tablets but the taste made my migraine worse and they weren't as effective.  Now I am back to taking the pill version!  My migraine symptoms were severe pain in temples and back of head which would lead to vomiting.
This medication may be easy to take but it does not work and it has a HORRIBLE taste that makes me sick. I do not recommend this to anyone, also it is rather expensive...definately not worth it

column2: 19-24 Female  (Patient)
column9: I have suffered debilitating migraines since I was 12 years old; Migraines that would put me out for literally days at a time, make me violently ill from pain, making me sensitive to all sounds, lights, and smells. I would get to the point where I would curl into a ball on the floor and want to slam my head into the door, and nothing would work. I tried Topomax, Imitrex, Propranolol and a vast array of pain medications and "trigger shots". My new doctor prescribed me Maxalt, and it seemed to make my migraine go away within minutes. I know reactions to this drug depends on the person who takes it, but the only thing I personally felt from it was sort of that "buzzing" feeling in my body that most Narcotics would tend to have on me. I would recommend at least trying this once to anyone who has ever suffered a migraine, because in my opinion, the chance you take couldn't be worse than a crippling migraine.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years
45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have suffered with migraines for about 20 years, doctors and I feel it's related to perimenopause, and now menopause.  Need to take it fairly soon after migraine starts,  and lie down in a quiet, darkened place, or at least lay my head down, for 15-20 minutes to work most effectively.  If I wait too long, even Maxalt won't work for me, so I try to make very sure I carry it with me wherever I go.  Usually, my migraines last 1-3 days, and I need two to four doses over those days to keep my migraine subdued.  For those of us who have had migraines for years, you know what I mean--it's always there, even if far in the background, until you know it is finally gone.  Then you feel like a miracle walking--until the next one.  If I am at work, I need to stay pretty busy, or I will get tired from the Maxalt.  It usually makes me feel groggy, so I have to watch it if I must drive, but the grogginess feeling is SOOOO much better than the pain and light/noise/touch sensitivity.  Maxalt has worked the best for me of all the meds I've tried. Imitrex had some really awful side effects, and stopped working for me after a few years.  Have used Maxalt, at a doctor's recommendation, for about 7 years now.  No severe side effects that I can't live without.  Am still waiting for menopause to end, and hope the migraines will, too.

column2: 25-34 Male  (Patient)
column9: I experienced unpleasant anxiety and visual hallucinations at the onset of the effect of the drug. Although my migraine usual have visual 'hallucination'/distortions, these were dissimilar and unpleasant, the anxiety associated with the medication was almost as debilitating as a migraine, I can't consider this to be a viable option for treating the onset of a migraine for that reason. Although my headache didn't persist after the initial unpleasant effects, that lasted up to 30-45 minutes.

ok when i was on maxalt i had gotten extream jaw pressure and pain nothing wolud help me except sleep but since the pain was so bad !!! i didnt get to sleep

column2: Lisa, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have never had migraine headaches before. I have had an occational stress headache. Or maybe a self inflicted one from alcohol drinks. I've having really bad ones,for no reason. I realized it was a migraine when my usual Mortrin,Excederin,etc.. didn't work. I was sensitive to sound and light. My PA gave me a sample on this. I didn't have to take the second dose, Untill two days later it happened again. I took the Maxalt and sat with an icepack on my head, about 1hr it was better. I could put the ice pack away and get up. I don't feel totally better,but well enough to sit at the computer. I hope it stays this way because I don't have another pill. I amy 37 years old and scared to death because it is so different than the usual headache. I am afraid of the worst. Why all of a sudden is this happening? Yesterday I was fine no stress, or do I smoke, and didn't drink. Just afraid but glad I had a sample.

column9: I have tried many other drugs, but none give the relief as quickly and fully as Maxhalt does. I have been using it for several years now and would not like to be without.

column2: PMS, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had been suffering from incapacitating "sinus headaches" on the first day of my period for years.  I was prescribed diuretics, muscle relaxers, barbituates, and have tried every over-the- counter medication available with no relief.  I switched doctors and my new doctor said that my sinus headaches could be migrains.  He prescribed Maxalt, and I have not had to suffer for more than about an hour every month, and I haven't had to miss work or anything else because of these headaches.  Maxalt is a godsend for me.  The medications gives me a weird feeling in my eyes and face, but it is definately preferable to the headache.
Maxalt is the only drug that has worked for me. I also don't have as much nausea if I take it right away. I've been suffering from migraines since I was 5 or 6 (53 now) and this is a miracle for me.

column9: Maxalt is a miracle drug for me.  I have used it for the past 6 years.  I wish I had know about it sooner.  If I take it as soon as the aura begins, my headache never comes.  I tell all my migraine-suffering friends about it.  I should be a sales rep.  It truly is a miracle drug.

column2: kbark77, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been using Maxalt with great success for about 3 years. Usually within 15 to 45 mins. the pain is under control. I only wish the doctors would have recommended it sooner as I suffered many years before learning about this med.I am very thankful for it.

column2: vt_yeti, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: This drug is amazing. I suffer from classic migraines, so as soon as I get the aura, I drop the Maxalt and it allows me to function. With Maxalt, I can keep going; not as effective at work as usual, since I get a little spacy, but I don't have to stop everything like before. I do get a kind of weird side effect--achey shoulders; it feels like I've been carrying a 50-lb. pack around for a couple of days. Now if only they could come up with something to stop the migraines entirely...
